source.name: DC Department of Public Works
source.notes: Based on DC DPW and Zero Waste DC guidelines. DC accepts a wide range of rigid plastics in blue bin. Food waste composting available through Compost Crew partnership.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: DC accepts PET, HDPE, LDPE, PP, and PS rigid plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still inside

materials.name: Plastic containers
notes: DC accepts rigid plastic containers including tubs, cups, and clamshells
Must be rigid plastic (not film or bags)
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food residue
No styrofoam; rigid plastics only

materials.name: Corrugated cardboard
instructions: Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: No wax-coated cardboard
Break down boxes so they fit
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated cardboard
Remove styrofoam inserts

materials.name: Paperboard packaging
instructions: Remove plastic liner if present (trash it)
notes: Thin paperboard is accepted in DC recycling
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove plastic liners

materials.name: Junk mail
notes: All junk mail is recyclable in DC
commonMistakes: Don't shred first; whole pieces recycle better

materials.name: Magazines
notes: Glossy paper is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples; they're fine

materials.name: Newspapers
notes: Inserts and supplements can stay
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Office paper
notes: Staples and paper clips are fine
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Envelopes
notes: Padded/bubble mailers: remove bubble lining (trash it) and recycle paper part
commonMistakes: Don't include bubble-lined mailers without separating

materials.name: Books
instructions: Soft and hard cover books accepted in blue bin
Remove non-paper covers if heavily laminated
notes: DC Public Library accepts donations
Books are recyclable in DC
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags soiled with food

materials.name: Kraft paper / brown paper
notes: Plain brown paper is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated kraft paper

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
notes: Aseptic and gable-top cartons accepted in DC
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid inside

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if can still has pressure

materials.name: Aluminum foil and pie pans
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food

materials.name: Metal food / beverage containers
notes: Labels can stay on
Includes aluminum and steel/tin cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
notes: All colors of glass accepted in DC
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics

materials.name: Food waste / food scraps
instructions: DC has a food waste composting program
Sign up for Compost Crew or use a DC community composting site
Accepted: fruit, vegetables, bread, grains, coffee grounds, tea bags, eggshells
notes: DC's composting program is expanding through partnerships
Multiple farmers market and community drop-off sites available
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling bin
Check composting site for specific accepted items

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: DC collects yard waste separately from trash
Place in paper bags or open containers labeled 'yard waste'
Branches must be bundled and cut to 4 feet or less
notes: Yard waste is collected seasonally by DC DPW
Check DPW website for collection schedule
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't mix with regular trash

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
Take to grocery stores (Giant, Safeway, Harris Teeter) for film recycling
notes: DC charges a 5-cent bag fee to reduce plastic bag use
Most grocery stores in DC accept bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Never put film plastic in the blue bin

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: DC banned expanded polystyrene food service ware in 2016
notes: DC's foam ban means less styrofoam in the waste stream
Packing styrofoam still goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the blue bin

materials.name: Plastic wrap and film
instructions: Or take to grocery store film drop-off
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Paper plates and napkins
instructions: Food-soiled paper products: place in compost if you have access to DC composting
notes: DC composting sites may accept food-soiled paper; check with your provider
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the blue bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to a DC Household Hazardous Waste drop-off event
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: DC holds periodic HHW collection events
Some hardware stores accept batteries
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to a DC e-waste recycling event or drop-off location
notes: DC holds periodic electronics recycling events
Check zerowaste.dc.gov for schedule
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or blue bin

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to DC Household Hazardous Waste collection event
Latex paint: can dry out with kitty litter and trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to HHW
notes: DC holds HHW events multiple times per year
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to DC HHW collection event
Auto parts stores may also accept used oil
notes: Never pour down drains
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or into storm drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to DC drug take-back locations
CVS and Walgreens in DC participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal, and trash
notes: MPD holds periodic drug take-back events
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or DC thrift stores
Textile recycling bins at various DC locations
notes: DC has many clothing donation options
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to DC HHW event or Home Depot/Lowe's
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in trash

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
notes: DC charges a 5-cent fee on disposable cups
Plastic lids: recycle in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in recycling

materials.name: Receipts
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Candy wrappers
notes: Wrappers look metallic but are multi-layer plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Chip bags / snack bags
notes: Metallized film; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Greasy pizza boxes: compost if you have access to DC composting
Clean portions: tear off and recycle in blue bin
If no composting access: trash the greasy parts
notes: DC composting sites accept food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put grease-soaked cardboard in the blue bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Or take plastic film to store drop-off bins
notes: Plastic film not accepted in DC curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Take to DC HHW event or restaurant oil recycling programs
notes: Grease causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to DC HHW collection event
Never put in trash or recycling
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in trash

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Take to DC HHW event or pharmacy take-back
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in trash or recycling

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk trash pickup through DC DPW 311
notes: DC DPW collects bulk items by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Place at curb on scheduled day
notes: DC DPW handles bulk item collection
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or DC e-waste recycling event
Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: Wipe personal data before disposal
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Place in DC compost collection if enrolled
Multiple farmers market drop-off sites available
notes: DC food waste composting accepts all fruit
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in DC compost collection if enrolled
notes: All vegetable scraps accepted in DC composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Most DC composting programs do not accept meat or bones
notes: Check with your specific composting provider for accepted items
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Rinse and recycle containers separately in blue bin
notes: Container goes in blue bin; contents go in trash or compost
commonMistakes: Rinse the container before recycling it

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Place in DC compost collection if enrolled
Paper filters and paper tea bags accepted
Drop off at DC farmers market composting sites
notes: Coffee grounds are one of the most commonly composted items
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh

materials.name: Pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
commonMistakes: Never compost pet waste
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
notes: Wax/silicone coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in trash
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in recycling

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
notes: Some stores give credit for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to DC HHW event or Home Depot/Lowe's
notes: Contains mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Don't break them

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer or DC recycling event
notes: Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Mixed plastic; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Nail polish is hazardous

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: place in blue recycling bin
Styrofoam egg cartons: place in trash
notes: Only paper-based cartons are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Most wrapping paper: trash (glitter, foil, or lamination)
Plain paper wrapping with no coating: recycle in blue bin
notes: Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched it may be paper and recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable

materials.name: Cleaning products / chemicals
instructions: Take to DC HHW collection event
Empty bottles that held non-hazardous cleaners: rinse and recycle if rigid plastic
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down drains

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Place loose metal lids inside a metal can and crimp shut
notes: Small loose lids can fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put loose small caps directly in bin

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Food-soiled wrappers: trash (or compost if enrolled)
Clean paper wrappers: blue recycling bin
notes: Greasy paper is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Too small to sort at recycling facility
notes: Shredded paper clogs equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in blue bin

recycle: Rigid plastic bottles and containers (PET, HDPE, LDPE, PP, PS)

tips: All items must be dry and empty before recycling
Use the 'What Goes Where?' tool at zerowaste.dc.gov for item lookup
DC accepts a wide range of rigid plastics in the blue bin
DC charges a 5-cent fee on disposable bags and cups
Food waste composting available through Compost Crew and community drop-off sites
Yard waste is collected separately by DC DPW
Never bag recyclables in plastic bags

locations.name: Fort Totten Transfer Station
locations.address: 4900 John McCormack Dr NE, Washington, DC 20011
locations.notes: DC DPW transfer station open to residents.

locations.name: Benning Road Transfer Station
locations.notes: Accepts bulk and yard waste from DC residents.

locations.name: DC Household Hazardous Waste Events
locations.notes: DC holds multiple HHW collection events per year at rotating locations.
